tn.text: David's song to Yahweh starts. He uses parallelism to emphasize what he is saying. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: out of the hand of all his enemies, and out of the hand of Saul
tn.text: This is a progression from enemies in general to one specific enemy of David, King Saul.
This metonym means "out of the power of." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Yahweh is my rock, my fortress
tn.text: This metaphor shows a progression from a part, "rock," to the whole, "fortress." A fortress is built of many large rocks. This means Yahweh has the strength to protect his people from harm. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
David's song to Yahweh continues. He uses parallelism to emphasize what he is saying. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: God is my rock ... He is my shield, the horn of my salvation, my stronghold
tn.text: All of these metaphors are symbols of God's strength and power. They emphasize God's ability to protect and save his people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: who is worthy to be praised
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "who is worthy to receive praise" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: I will be saved from my enemies
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "he will save me from my enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
David's song to Yahweh continues. He uses parallelism to emphasize what he is saying. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: For the waves of death surrounded me, the rushing waters of destruction overwhelmed me
tn.text: David compares the wicked men who wanted to kill him to flood waters that are about to drown him. These sentences have similar meanings and are used for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This is a picture of fast-flowing flood waters that destroy everything in their path.

tn.ref: The cords of Sheol surrounded me; the snares of death trapped me
tn.text: David speaks about death and Sheol as if they are people who are trying to trap him as a hunter traps an animal. These phrases have similar meanings and are used for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] )
David's song to Yahweh continues. He uses parallelism to emphasize what he is saying. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"In my great trouble"

tn.ref: he heard my voice from his temple
tn.text: David is referring to the heavenly temple where Yahweh dwells. The earthly temple has not yet been built.

tn.ref: my call for help went into his ears
tn.text: Here the metonym "his ears" refers to Yahweh and his hearing of David's call for help. AT: "he heard my prayer for help" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
David speaks of Yahweh as if he had ears. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
David's song to Yahweh continues. He uses parallelism to emphasize what he is saying. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Then the earth shook ... were ignited by it
tn.text: This is Yahweh's response to David's cry for help from his enemies. David uses the imagery of the earth shaking and fire coming from Yahweh to emphasize Yahweh's terrible anger. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
David speaks of the two extremes to include everything in creation. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])

tn.ref: and were shaken, because God was angry
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "because God's anger shook them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
David speaks of Yahweh as if he had these humans parts. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

Here Yahweh's anger is compared to fire, which causes coals to ignite and burn. AT: "The flame from his mouth set coals on fire" or "He also sent burning coals from his mouth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
David's song to Yahweh continues. He uses parallelism to emphasize what he is saying. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: He opened the heavens ... rain clouds in the skies
tn.text: David describes Yahweh's way of saving David from his enemies as a storm cloud gathering over a place. This emphasizes God's power and his anger. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
David speaks of God as having feet like humans. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: He was seen on the wings of the wind
tn.text: This can be translated in active form. AT: "He appeared on the wings of the wind" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This expression speaks of the wind as if it were a bird. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: He made darkness a tent around him
tn.text: Here the darkness Yahweh creates is compared to a tent which hides him completely. AT:"He hid himself in the darkness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
David's song to Yahweh continues. He uses parallelism to emphasize what he is saying. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: From the lightning before him ... lightning bolts and dispersed them
tn.text: David continues describing Yahweh, whom he compares to a storm, coming to save him from his enemies. This emphasizes God's power and anger towards David's enemies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: From the lightning before him coals of fire fell
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "Out of his bright light he sent burning coals" or 2) "From his brightness he sent lightning"

tn.ref: The Most High shouted. He shot arrows
tn.text: David describes Yahweh doing these actions a person would do. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
David compares the lightning from Yahweh's storm to arrows that a soldier would use. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This continues David's song to Yahweh. He uses parallelism to emphasize what he is saying. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Then the water channels appeared ... breath of his nostrils
tn.text: When Yahweh shouted in his attack against David's enemies, it is compared to his power to create upheaval in the deepest parts of the ocean and the earth. This shows his great power and fierce anger. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

David compares Yahweh's anger to turbulent movements of the ground. "This can be stated in active form. AT: "Yahweh's battle cry exposed the foundations of the world" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This continues David's song to Yahweh. He uses parallelism to emphasize what he is saying. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
David compares his enemies to a flood that threatens to drown him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: He rescued me from my strong enemy
tn.text: David's enemies were overwhelming. He praises God for delivering him from all his enemies.
This continues David's song to Yahweh. He uses parallelism to emphasize what he is saying. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: They came against me on the day of my distress
tn.text: "My enemies fought against me when I was in great trouble"
The word "day" represents the span of time when David was in distress. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"but Yahweh supported me" or "but Yahweh helped me"
This refers to a place where there was no danger and his enemies could not trap him.

tn.ref: to the measure of the cleanness of my hands
tn.text: Here "cleanness of my hands" means the same as "righteousness." AT: "because I obey his commands" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
David continues his song to Yahweh.

tn.ref: I have kept the ways of Yahweh
tn.text: Here "the ways of Yahweh" refers to how Yahweh wants his people to act. This means David has done what Yahweh commands.
This means David constantly reads and thinks about God's decrees.
David continues his song to Yahweh.

tn.ref: I have kept myself from sin
tn.text: This refers to choosing not to sin against Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: to the degree of my cleanness in his sight
tn.text: Here "my cleanness" means the same as "my righteousness." AT: "because he knows that I have done what he commands" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
David continues his song to Yahweh.

tn.ref: you are perverse to the twisted
tn.text: Here "perverse" means to be cunning or crafty, and "twisted" means to turn away from what is good and right. This means God is wise in how he deals with wicked people.
David continues his song to Yahweh.

tn.ref: your eyes are against the proud
tn.text: Here the metonym "your eyes" refers to what Yahweh sees. This means Yahweh watches the proud person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
"and you destroy their pride"

tn.ref: you are my lamp, Yahweh. Yahweh lights up my darkness
tn.text: This metaphor compares Yahweh to a lamp, which means he gives David light and helps him to see when things seem hopeless. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
David continues his song to Yahweh.

tn.ref: I can run over a barricade
tn.text: Here "barricade" may refer to a group of soldiers or to a stone wall. Either way it means God enables David to defeat his enemies.

tn.ref: I can leap over a wall
tn.text: David is exaggerating to emphasize Yahweh's help. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: The word of Yahweh is pure
tn.text: "Everything Yahweh says is true"
The metaphor "a shield" emphasizes God's power to protect his people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
David continues his song to Yahweh.

tn.ref: For who is God except Yahweh, and who is a rock except our God?
tn.text: David uses this question to emphasize that there is no God apart from Yahweh. These may be translated as statements. AT: "Yahweh alone is God. Our God alone is a rock." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
David compares Yahweh to a rock to emphasize his strength and ability to protect his people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: he leads the blameless person on his path
tn.text: Yahweh keeps the blameless person safe and removes anything that may harm him.
David continues his song to Yahweh.

tn.ref: He makes my feet swift like a deer and places me on the high hills
tn.text: Here David's feet are compared to those of a deer using exaggeration. Yahweh gives David the strength to move quickly and provides secure places for protection and rest. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
Both of these refer to David. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: to bend a bow of bronze
tn.text: Only a very strong man could use a bow made from metal.
David continues his song to Yahweh.
David compares Yahweh's power to save him to a shield that protects a soldier from his enemy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
God answered David's prayers and granted him blessings and success over his enemies.

tn.ref: You have made a wide place for my feet beneath me
tn.text: Yahweh has put David in a safe place where his enemies cannot trap him. "Feet" refers to David's ability to stand securely. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
David continues his song to Yahweh.
"chased my enemies"

tn.ref: I devoured them and smashed them
tn.text: Here David compares himself to a wild animal. AT: "I completely destroyed them like a wild animal devouring its prey" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "feet" refers to the power and control of victory over his enemies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
David continues his song to Yahweh.

tn.ref: You put strength on me like a belt for battle
tn.text: Here the strength that Yahweh gives is compared to a belt for battle that allowed David to do mighty things. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: you put under me those who rise up against me
tn.text: "you helped me defeat those who fought against me"

tn.ref: the back of my enemies' necks
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) David seeing the backs of the enemy as they run away or 2) David putting his foot on the back of his enemy's neck after he defeats him.
"I completely destroyed"
David continues his song to Yahweh.
"My enemies cried"

tn.ref: they cried out to Yahweh, but he did not answer them
tn.text: The time for Yahweh's judgment had come upon them.

tn.ref: like dust on the ground ... like mud in the streets
tn.text: This means that David completely destroyed his enemies. These two phrases "like dust on the ground" and "like mud on the streets" have a similar meaning and are used for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
David continues his song to Yahweh.

tn.ref: from the disputes of my own people
tn.text: This refers to those among the Israelites who rebelled against King David.

tn.ref: You have kept me as the head of nations
tn.text: "You placed me as ruler over the nations." Here "nations" refers to other nations besides Israel.

tn.ref: A people that I have not known
tn.text: "A foreign people"

tn.ref: Foreigners were forced to bow to me
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Foreigners bowed down to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: May my rock be praised. May God be exalted
tn.text: These sentences have similar meaning and are used for emphasis.  These may be stated in active form. AT: "May everyone praise my rock. May everyone exalt God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:[[figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
David compares Yahweh to a rock to emphasize his power to protect his people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the one who brings down peoples under me
tn.text: "the one who puts the people of other nations under my rule"

tn.ref: you lifted me up above those who rose up against me
tn.text: "you saved me from my enemies and gave me honor"
"from those who want to harm me"
David concludes his song to Yahweh.
Here the metonym "name" refers to Yahweh's reputation. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: and he shows his covenant loyalty to his anointed one
tn.text: Here David may be referring to the promises Yahweh made in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:07:08|7:8]]
